unnormalised: Indian manufacturers are increasingly prioritizing robust quality control measures across their supply chains, recognizing its vital role in global competitiveness. A recent survey by the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) highlighted that nearly 65% of companies are investing in enhanced inspection technologies.

unnormalised: Experts at IIT Madras are collaborating with local SMEs to implement AI-powered quality checks, reducing defects by an estimated 20%. This tech includes automated optical inspection (AOI) and advanced data analytics.

unnormalised: "Think of making the perfect biryani," says Ms. Priya Sharma, a quality control manager at a textile factory in Surat. "If any ingredient isn't right, the whole dish suffers. Same with manufacturing; every component matters."

unnormalised: Leading automotive component manufacturer, Mahindra Auto Parts, recently announced a Rs. 50 crore investment in upgrading its quality testing infrastructure, targeting zero-defect production by 2025. This focus on quality comes ahead of the festive season, as demand surges prior to Diwali, and consumers expect flawless products. Maintaining stringent quality standards is especially crucial for exports, with demand steady from markets like the US and Europe for products ranging from engineering goods to handloom textiles. Even traditional industries are embracing newer methods, like ultrasonic testing in metal casting, to guarantee durability, for instance, in components destined for projects like the Delhi-Mumbai Industrial Corridor spanning over 1500 km.
